[SYNTAX]: Complex sentences may be challenging to follow

[STRUCTURE]: Sudden transition between library anecdote and bushman story

[SYNTAX]: Complex sentence structures may slightly hinder readability (e.g., long sentences with multiple clauses).
[LEXICON]: Some archaic phrasing ("it gives one bookman whom I know the keenest pleasure") could confuse modern readers.
[PUNCTUATION]: Ellipses and em-dashes used liberally, occasionally disrupting flow.

[LOGIC]: Sudden shift from character dialogue to abstract literary critique without clear transition.
[STRUCTURE]: Dense metaphors (e.g., books as houses/cathedrals) require reader effort to follow connections.
[TRANSITION]: Jump from French critic's quote to cathedral metaphor lacks explicit linkage.
